title: Post-Surgical Mixed Hearing Loss with Recent Decline
chief_complaint: I'm worried my cholesteatoma has come back because my hearing in the left ear has gotten worse recently. I'm also having drainage, pain, and ringing in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Long-standing history with recent acute worsening.
problem_summary.course: Chronic post-surgical status; recent decline in hearing sensitivity.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Otorrhea (drainage), otalgia (pain), tinnitus, concern for cholesteatoma recurrence.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Noted decrease in hearing ability in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Determine cause of recent symptoms and rule out recurrence of pathology.

history.present_illness: Patient reports recent decrease in hearing in the left ear accompanied by drainage, pain, and tinnitus.
history.otologic_history: History of cholesteatoma removal (left ear) many years ago. Post-operative complications included otorrhea determined to be a CSF leak, which was subsequently repaired.
history.prior_management: Previous surgeries for cholesteatoma and CSF leak repair.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows flat slight to mild sensorineural hearing loss. Left ear shows moderately severe rising to moderate mixed hearing loss, sloping back to moderately severe in high frequencies.

numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: ~60 dB HL at 250 Hz, improving to ~45 dB HL at 1-2 kHz, sloping to ~65 dB HL at 4-8 kHz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with PTA for both ears. Word recognition scores are excellent (100%) bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal. Left ear flat tympanogram with large ear canal volume (consistent with mastoid cavity or perforation).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes for both ears from 500 to 4000 Hz. Decay could not be measured.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a slight to mild sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear and a mixed hearing loss in the left ear (moderately severe to moderate degree). Speech understanding remains excellent in both ears when speech is loud enough. Immittance testing indicates a patent mastoid cavity or perforation in the left ear (large volume) and unexplained absent reflexes in the right ear.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms the mixed hearing loss in your left ear, which means there is both a nerve component and a mechanical component (likely related to your previous surgeries).
The 'large volume' reading on the pressure test in your left ear is consistent with your history of ear surgery (mastoidectomy) or a perforation.
Given your symptoms of drainage, pain, and hearing change, immediate medical follow-up is necessary.
We are referring you back to the ENT physician to rule out a recurrence of the cholesteatoma or a new fluid leak.
notes_for_actor: Portray anxiety regarding the potential return of the cholesteatoma.
Emphasize that the right ear feels 'normal' to you, despite the test showing slight loss.
Be specific about the physical sensations in the left ear: wetness (drainage) and pain.
